title: 109_s765
content: The Act may be cited as the "Math and Science Incentive Act of 2005". Congress finds that the United States needs a strong scientific and technical enterprise, requiring more scientists and engineers. The education system must encourage students to study science and math, as current performance lags behind international peers. The US must recommit to leadership in science, math, and engineering, especially with advancements like nanotechnology. Loan forgiveness programs are needed to attract talent. A loan forgiveness program is essential to attract students to careers in science, mathematics, engineering, and technology, including teaching, to help the United States maintain its technological leadership amidst advancements in nanotechnology. Establishment of program for loan forgiveness in science, mathematics, engineering, and technology fields to support technological leadership in the United States. The Secretary will assume interest payments on loans for eligible borrowers who are teachers of STEM subjects or professionals in those fields. The Secretary will assume interest payments on loans for eligible borrowers who are teachers or professionals in STEM fields, who agree to complete 5 years of service in a qualifying position. Interest limitations apply to loans under specific conditions, and participants are selected based on eligibility criteria. The Secretary selects eligible applicants for the program based on national security, homeland security, and economic security needs of the US, academic record or job performance, likelihood to complete the 5-year service obligation, and remain in science, mathematics, or engineering after service completion. The Secretary selects eligible applicants based on national security needs, academic record, and likelihood to complete the service obligation in science, mathematics, or engineering. Loan interest payments are subject to appropriations, with priority given to previous recipients. The Secretary may prescribe regulations for implementation. Interest payments begin on the effective date of the agreement. The selected individual begins the service obligation period upon agreement effective date, which ends after loan repayment, $10,000 payment by the Secretary, failure to fulfill obligation, or exceeding income threshold. The Secretary will pay the interest that accrues on a loan of a student borrower selected under the regulations. Eligible individuals must submit an application for loan interest payment, agreeing to repay the amount if they fail to complete the required service period. The Secretary will pay the interest on a loan for selected student borrowers who agree to repay if they do not complete the required service period. Consolidation loans may qualify for interest payment if used to repay specific types of loans. Borrowers cannot receive benefits from both this program and certain loan forgiveness programs. The Secretary will pay the interest on a loan for selected student borrowers who agree to repay if they do not complete the required service period. Borrowers cannot receive benefits from both this program and certain loan forgiveness programs. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Education, and "mathematics, science, or engineering professional" is defined as someone with a degree in science, mathematics, or engineering working in a related field, including as a professor at a higher education institution. SEC. 5. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal year 2006 and the following 5 years to implement this Act.
